I realized today after googling for a […]

messages.text: As someone having this channel as my only entry point to the broad world of programming related blog posts, I'm always puzzled. I have no idea of their relevance or whether they have audience and not a single clue to how the people sharing them discovered them in the first place. Also I am amazed by how plentiful they are.

messages.text:
I wrote a python script for the first time in a year or so yesterday, and I realized that I don't much like the way of performing a function using the dot-accessor after the variable. Like
```foo = "water melon"
foo.split()[0]```
It just feels a little weird. Totes not a deal breaker or anything.

elements.text: I wrote a python script for the first time in a year or so yesterday, and I realized that I don't much like the way of performing a function using the dot-accessor after the variable. Like

foo = "water melon"
foo.split()[0]
It just feels a little weird. Totes not a deal breaker or anything.

messages.text:
I wanted to know how a particular thing that involved wrapping a C-library was done.
So I was like _“I will take a glance at the python library that wraps that C library. See how they do it”_
But no.
The “python” wrapper, is itself implemented about 50% in C.
Because of course it is.

elements.text:

messages.text: no, `=` is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

messages.text: I wonder if it would be completely insane to allow all binary operators to also be defined as macros?  seems like it would have a ton of really nice uses, but on the other hand it could get horribly confusing if people don't use this power responsibly

messages.text:
So LLVM Fortran has a REPL now:
<https://twitter.com/lfortranorg/status/1367507839535640578>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/lfortranorg|@lfortranorg>: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>

messages.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis. <https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175>), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl? <@U687RKK0E>

attachments.title: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system
attachments.text: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system Previously I wrote about how the full generality of the Swift generic system is undecidable. The basic idea is that "finitely-presented monoids" can be written as a Swift protocol where the "word problem" on the monoid reduces to proving an equivalence between two types. Since the word problem is known to be undecidable, this shows that Swift generics (as currently defined) are undecidable. In that post, we started with a finitely-presented ...
attachments.fallback: Swift Forums: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system

elements.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis.
), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl?

messages.text:
Regarding "some nice way for Julia to provide value to the PyTorch ecosystem now."

I can see a couple of approaches: 1. Writing custom GPU /TPU kernels in Julia, which can be called from pytorch, with automatic wrapper generation. <@U69BL50BF> might be able to comment on that.

2. Writing custom array or scalar types in Julia, for pytorch

3. Symbolic simplification and optimization of pytorch code using modeling toolkit and <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-symbolics-jl-a-modern-computer-algebra-system-for-a-modern-language/56251/119>

4.  moving aten/ torch  backend from C++ to Julia. More people from the community can hack on that vs c++.

Anyone else have other ideas?

root.text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms: <https://twitter.com/cHHillee/status/1367621541693857794>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/cHHillee|@cHHillee>: Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>
attachments.text:
Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>

messages.text: <@UN3R6SDDW> another non sciml oft ignored advantage of source to source autodiff is that  integration with host language and custom types allows one to write use facing apps where the ML is deeply integrated into the meat of the app. The (now defunct) swift for tensorflow example was iirc,  an audio player which  adjusts dynamically to user behavior. Julia's nascent WASM compilation can be leveraged here so people can write ML driven apps for web, mobile and serverside

root.text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms: <https://twitter.com/cHHillee/status/1367621541693857794>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/cHHillee|@cHHillee>: Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>
attachments.text:
Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>

elements.text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms:

another non sciml oft ignored advantage of source to source autodiff is that  integration with host language and custom types allows one to write use facing apps where the ML is deeply integrated into the meat of the app. The (now defunct) swift for tensorflow example was iirc,  an audio player which  adjusts dynamically to user behavior. Julia's nascent WASM compilation can be leveraged here so people can write ML driven apps for web, mobile and serverside

messages.text: I wonder if anyone has modeled the half life of the caps that come on usb sticks.  I think I average about 2 hours from getting a new usb stick until the plastic end cap it came with is lost forever.

messages.text: Another weird question... How many of you professionally have run into upper management having fetishes for "no code" tools that do not do the task that they want done? Both places I've most recently worked at have this as a super common point of contention...

messages.text: <https://mobile.twitter.com/andy_kelley/status/1371599525467484163|https://mobile.twitter.com/andy_kelley/status/1371599525467484163>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/andy_kelley|@andy_kelley>: Huge success! In this stream we converted the build system of Redis to Zig, then cross compiled Redis from Linux to macOS M1, and it worked!

Kudos to <https://twitter.com/kubkon|@kubkon> for his brilliant work on Zig's self-hosted Mach-O linker code.

<https://vimeo.com/524007646> <https://twitter.com/croloris/status/1371546880652537860>
attachments.text:
Huge success! In this stream we converted the build system of Redis to Zig, then cross compiled Redis from Linux to macOS M1, and it worked!

Kudos to <https://twitter.com/kubkon|@kubkon> for his brilliant work on Zig's self-hosted Mach-O linker code.

<https://vimeo.com/524007646> <https://twitter.com/croloris/status/1371546880652537860>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/croloris|@croloris>: 20 mins from now <https://twitter.com/andy_kelley|@andy_kelley> and I will do part 3 of the "Transitioning Redis to Zig" series on his Twitch channel. 

He promised high octane dvorak Makefile dismantling action, so strap in before opening the link!

<https://www.twitch.tv/andrewrok>
